column2:
A 62-year-old Chinese man first presented to our hospital in October 2014 for worsening of low mood. At that time, he had just been seen by a private psychiatrist and was diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Aside from the depressive symptoms, he also manifested with strong nihilistic delusions. He did not have any significant physical health conditions. The patient was subsequently admitted to our hospital as a case of major depressive disorder with psychotic features and treated with mirtazapine 30 mg every night, venlafaxine 150 mg every morning, and risperidone 1 mg every night. During his hospitalization, he also underwent six sessions of electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) and improved significantly after 2 months on the ward.

Upon discharge, he was maintained on mirtazapine, venlafaxine, and risperidone for 2 years. In 2016, risperidone was discontinued. In 2018, due to his stable mood, venlafaxine was also discontinued, and he was only maintained on mirtazapine 30 mg every night. Over the years, he was continued on mirtazapine with doses fluctuating between 15 and 30 mg daily depending on the stress that he experienced at that time. He did not display any manic or hypomanic symptoms during this long period when he was only on mirtazapine. He managed to resume work as a school cleaner and continued on through the years with no significant issues. He was on 6-monthly follow-ups and had been generally compliant with his antidepressant medication.

The patient was apparently well until May 2023 when he was 71 years old. He was then brought to our hospital again by his relatives for evaluation after a change in behavior for 2 weeks. The patient was observed to have significant mood swings and was described to be very active and irritable. He was also noted to have started sending messages with grandiose content and overspending his money. He was physically aggressive toward his relatives, prompting them to bring him to our psychiatric emergency room for evaluation. During the consult, the patient's mood was observed to be labile. His thought process was largely goal directed but was noted to be interspersed with tangential and at times incoherent responses. He endorsed a decreased need for sleep, racing thoughts, and grandiose delusions. The patient did not take any illicit drugs and did not have any family history of mental illness. There were also no new medications given to him recently. Due to the acute change in his mental state, he received a comprehensive organic workup where blood examination revealed unremarkable results.
column3: Bipolar 1 disorder
column5:
Hmm, this is a complex psychiatric case with a longitudinal history. The patient initially presented with major depressive disorder with psychotic features, responded well to treatment including ECT, and remained stable for many years on maintenance medication. 

The key twist is the acute behavioral change at age 71 with new manic symptoms - mood swings, irritability, grandiosity, overspending, aggression, decreased need for sleep, racing thoughts, and grandiose delusions. This occurred while only on mirtazapine, with no substance use or medical triggers found.

Given the history of major depression followed by a clear manic episode later in life, bipolar I disorder seems the most fitting primary diagnosis. The grandiose delusions during the current episode indicate psychotic features. The initial depressive episode with nihilistic delusions was severe enough to require hospitalization and ECT, which supports the bipolar diagnosis in retrospect.

For differentials, major depression with psychotic features should be listed since that was the original presentation. Delirium needs consideration given the acute onset in an older adult, though workup was negative. Late-onset psychotic disorders like delusional disorder are possible but less likely given the mood symptoms. Schizoaffective disorder could be considered given the combination of mood and psychotic symptoms across episodes.

The timeline and symptom progression strongly point to bipolar I as the unifying diagnosis, with the 2023 episode meeting criteria for a manic episode with psychotic features.
column6:
1. Bipolar I Disorder, current episode manic, with psychotic features (mood-congruent) - ICD-10 F31.2
2. Major Depressive Disorder, recurrent episode, severe with psychotic features (in partial remission, historical) - ICD-10 F33.3
3. Delirium (ruled out by workup, but initial presentation required exclusion) - ICD-10 F05
4. Delusional Disorder - ICD-10 F22
5. Schizoaffective Disorder, bipolar type - ICD-10 F25.0

column2: A 32-year-old male with a history of high-functioning ASD (living independently), depression, hypertension, and acid reflux disease was presented. Collateral information from the father confirmed a diagnosis of ASD that was based on detailed neuropsychological testing in childhood. His home medications included losartan 100 mg daily, famotidine 20 mg daily, and sertraline 50 mg daily. Patient shared that he was started on sertraline for his depressive symptoms 4 days ago, and he had taken his 4th dose that morning. He denied any previous history of antidepressant medication use. On the fourth day of sertraline 50 mg dosing, he presented himself to the emergency department (ED) during evening hours with complaints of restlessness and diffuse muscle stiffness; he felt his legs were “stiff and heavy,” and he “couldn't really move them” and also described “toes retching turning inwards” with an unusual but not painful sensation. On physical examination, he was noted to have bilateral upper extremity tremors, ocular clonus with lateral eye movement, and inducible clonus in his right ankle. Cranial nerve exams II-XII were normal, and deep tendon reflexes were not commented upon, so it is unclear if they were examined or not. Vital signs are notable for a heart rate of 61, blood pressure of 164/94, and oxygen saturation of 98% at room air. Routine lab work showed a normal complete blood count (CBC) with differential comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) that was unremarkable other than mild hypokalemia of 3.3 mEq/L. Urine drug screen was negative for any substances. Thyroid stimulating hormone level (TSH) and urinalysis were normal. Electrocardiogram (EKG) showed sinus rhythm with QTc of 403.
column3: Serotonin syndrome
column5:
Okay, I need to figure out the most likely diagnoses for this patient based on the vignette. Let me start by extracting and organizing the key information. The patient is a 32-year-old male with a history of high-functioning ASD, depression, hypertension, and acid reflux. He was started on sertraline four days ago for depressive symptoms, and on the fourth dose, he presented to the ED with restlessness, diffuse muscle stiffness, leg heaviness, toe retraction, tremors, ocular clonus, and inducible ankle clonus. Vital signs show elevated blood pressure and mild hypokalemia, but labs are otherwise normal, including a negative drug screen.

Hmm, the symptoms started shortly after initiating sertraline. Restlessness, muscle stiffness, tremors, clonus—these sound like neuromuscular and autonomic symptoms. The timing is critical here. Since the symptoms emerged after starting the SSRI, I need to consider conditions related to medication initiation.

What about serotonin syndrome? That fits. Serotonin syndrome can present with neuromuscular abnormalities like clonus, tremors, rigidity, and autonomic features such as elevated blood pressure. The patient has restlessness, muscle stiffness, tremors, ocular clonus, and inducible ankle clonus, along with hypertension. That aligns with the diagnostic criteria for serotonin syndrome. The fact that he just started sertraline supports this.

But wait, the patient has a history of ASD. Could that complicate things? Maybe, but the acute onset of symptoms right after starting the medication points more towards a medication-related issue. Also, the vignette mentions he denied previous antidepressant use, so this might be his first exposure to an SSRI, increasing the risk of serotonin syndrome.

Are there other possibilities? Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is another consideration, but he's not on antipsychotics. The medication list includes losartan, famotidine, and sertraline. No typical antipsychotics mentioned. So NMS is less likely.

Could it be a dystonic reaction? He has muscle stiffness and toe retraction, which might suggest acute dystonia. But the presence of clonus, tremors, and autonomic signs like hypertension makes serotonin syndrome more comprehensive.

What about his history of depression? He was started on sertraline for that. But the current presentation isn't typical for a depressive episode; it's more acute and physical. So depression is a background issue but not the primary reason for this ED visit.

His ASD is a chronic condition, well-documented since childhood. It's relevant for understanding the patient but doesn't explain the acute symptoms. Similarly, hypertension and acid reflux are managed with medications and don't directly cause these symptoms.

The lab results show mild hypokalemia. Could that contribute? Hypokalemia can cause muscle weakness or cramps, but not typically clonus, tremors, or autonomic instability. So it's probably incidental or a minor contributor.

Other differentials: Substance-induced symptoms? The drug screen was negative. Withdrawal from some substance? No history given. Medical conditions like encephalitis or seizures? No fever, headache, or altered mental status mentioned. The vignette doesn't suggest infection or structural issues.

Considering all this, serotonin syndrome seems the most likely. It's an adverse drug reaction to the SSRI. The primary diagnosis should be that. Then, his pre-existing conditions: ASD, depression, hypertension, acid reflux. But only psychiatric diagnoses with F-codes are needed, so hypertension and acid reflux aren't psychiatric. So the secondary diagnoses would be the pre-existing psychiatric conditions: ASD and depression. But he also has depression, which is why he was prescribed sertraline. That should be included. Possibly adjustment disorder or other anxiety disorders? Not mentioned. The vignette doesn't indicate any other active psychiatric symptoms beyond the depression for which he was treated.

Wait, the rubric says to list the top five most likely diagnoses with F-codes. The primary is serotonin syndrome. Then secondary could include his chronic conditions: ASD, major depressive disorder (since he's on sertraline for depression), and maybe substance-related issues? But the drug screen was negative, so that's out. Anxiety disorders? Not mentioned. Could there be an unspecified catatonia? The symptoms like stiffness and immobility might resemble catatonia, but the clonus and tremors point more towards serotonin syndrome. Also, catatonia often involves mutism, posturing, negativism, which aren't described here.

Another thought: akathisia? He has restlessness, which could be akathisia, often from antipsychotics or SSRIs. But he also has muscle stiffness and clonus, which are more characteristic of serotonin syndrome. Akathisia is primarily subjective restlessness and inability to stay still, but the other neurological signs here suggest a broader syndrome.

So, my differential list: serotonin syndrome as primary. Secondary: ASD, major depressive disorder. What else? Maybe substance-induced disorder? But drug screen negative. Other medication-induced movement disorders? Could be, but serotonin syndrome encompasses that.

The vignette says "do not include non-psychiatric diagnoses," so hypertension and acid reflux shouldn't be listed. So I need five psychiatric diagnoses. But the patient only has a few psychiatric conditions: ASD, depression, and now serotonin syndrome. Possibly adjustment disorder? Not mentioned. Anxiety? Not indicated. Maybe other specified anxiety disorder due to the restlessness? But it's likely part of serotonin syndrome.

Wait, perhaps I should consider other medication-induced conditions. For example, SSRI-induced movement disorders like dystonia or akathisia. But serotonin syndrome is a more encompassing diagnosis that includes these features. According to DSM-5-TR, serotonin syndrome is classified under "Medication-Induced Movement Disorders and Other Adverse Effects of Medication" and has specific criteria. So that's appropriate.

For ASD, that's F84.0. Depression could be unspecified depressive disorder or major depressive disorder. Since he was started on an SSRI for depressive symptoms, but no details on duration or criteria, it might be unspecified. However, the vignette says "depression" as a history, so I'll use the unspecified code.

Other possibilities: given his ASD, could there be comorbid anxiety? Often co-occurs, but not mentioned here. Similarly, OCD? Not indicated. So I'll stick with what's given.

So the top five: 
1. Serotonin syndrome (Medication-Induced Acute Dystonia or other movement disorder? Actually, serotonin syndrome is under T43.205A in ICD-10-CM, but for F-codes, it might be F19.99 for other medication-induced disorder. Wait, DSM-5-TR codes: Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome is under F06.8, but serotonin syndrome might be under F06.8 or F19.99. Let me think.

In DSM-5-TR, serotonin syndrome is categorized under "Other Adverse Effect of Medication" and can be coded based on the substance. Since it's due to sertraline, an SSRI, it would be under F19.99 for other substance-induced disorders, but SSRIs aren't typically considered substances of abuse. Alternatively, F06.8 for other specified mental disorders due to another medical condition? But serotonin syndrome is a medication effect.

Actually, looking up: Serotonin syndrome is not a DSM-5 diagnosis per se, but it can be classified as "Medication-Induced Movement Disorder" or "Other Substance-Induced Disorder." In ICD-10, it's T43.205A for adverse effect of SSRIs, but for psychiatric coding, it might be F06.8. I need to check standard coding.

Wait, the instruction says to use ICD-10 F-codes. So for serotonin syndrome, perhaps F06.8 (Other specified mental disorders due to brain damage and dysfunction and to physical disease). Or if it's considered a drug-induced condition, it might be F19.99 (Other psychoactive substance related disorders, unspecified). But sertraline isn't a psychoactive substance of abuse.

Given that, maybe the primary diagnosis is something else. Could this be Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome? But he's not on antipsychotics. However, SSRIs can rarely cause NMS-like symptoms. But serotonin syndrome is more common with SSRIs.

Another thought: Could it be Malignant Catatonia? The symptoms include rigidity, autonomic instability, but clonus is more typical of serotonin syndrome. Catatonia often has waxy flexibility, stupor, which aren't mentioned.

I think serotonin syndrome is correct. For coding, in DSM-5-TR, it's coded as 995.29 (ICD-10 T43.205A) but that's not an F-code. Since the requirement is F-codes, perhaps it's F06.8. Alternatively, if we consider it an adverse effect, it might not have a specific F-code. But the instruction says to provide F-codes for psychiatric diagnoses. Maybe I should list the chronic conditions first.

Wait, the vignette says "provide a structured list of DSM-5-TR psychiatric diagnoses" and "with corresponding ICD-10 F-codes." So I need to find appropriate F-codes for each.

Let me list likely diagnoses based on DSM-5-TR:
1. Serotonin Syndrome (under Medication-Induced Movement Disorders) – Code: F06.8 (Other specified mental disorders due to known physiological condition)
2. Autism Spectrum Disorder – F84.0
3. Major Depressive Disorder (or Depressive Disorder due to another medical condition? But he has hypertension, not clear) – Since he's on sertraline for depression, likely MDD, single or recurrent? Unspecified. Code: F32.9 (Major depressive disorder, single episode, unspecified) or F33.9 (Recurrent). The vignette doesn't specify, so F32.9 might be appropriate.
4. Other specified anxiety disorder? Not mentioned, but restlessness could be anxiety, but it's part of serotonin syndrome.
5. Substance-induced disorder? Drug screen negative.

Perhaps include "Other specified medication-induced movement disorder" if not serotonin syndrome. But serotonin syndrome is a specific condition.

Maybe the primary is Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome? But again, no antipsychotics. However, some sources suggest SSRIs can cause NMS. Less likely.

Given the symptoms, serotonin syndrome is most supported. So for the list:
Primary: Serotonin Syndrome – F06.8
Secondary: Autism Spectrum Disorder – F84.0
Secondary: Major Depressive Disorder – F32.9
But I need five diagnoses. Other possibilities: Anxiety disorder NOS? Not indicated. Adjustment disorder? No stressor mentioned. Perhaps "Other specified mental disorder due to another medical condition" for the hypertension? But that's not psychiatric. Or "Psychological factors affecting other medical conditions" – F54. That could be relevant if stress worsens hypertension, but not mentioned.

Maybe include "Medication-induced acute dystonia" as a separate diagnosis? But it's part of serotonin syndrome. Alternatively, given the history, "Other specified neurodevelopmental disorder"? But ASD covers that.

Perhaps "Unspecified catatonia" – F06.1? The symptoms include immobility and stiffness, but clonus is not typical. Catatonia often has other features like mutism, which aren't here.

Another idea: Could this be a somatic symptom disorder? Unlikely given the clear physical signs.

I think I'm overcomplicating. The patient has known ASD and depression, and now presents with serotonin syndrome. So those are three. For the remaining two, perhaps include other conditions in the differential that are less likely but possible. For example:
4. Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome – F06.8 (since it's a medication-induced condition)
5. Acute Dystonic Reaction – F06.8 or F44.4 (Conversion disorder with motor symptom? No, it's medication-induced).

But the instruction says "top 5 most likely diagnoses." So I should list the most likely ones based on the vignette. Serotonin syndrome is the acute issue. ASD and depression are chronic. That's three. What about "Other specified anxiety disorder" due to the restlessness? But it's likely part of serotonin syndrome.

Perhaps "Unspecified substance-induced disorder" but drug screen negative. Or "Other adverse effect of medication" not otherwise specified.

Wait, the rubric emphasizes diagnostic reasoning, but I'm not supposed to output clinical reasoning. So just the list. Based on the information, I think the primary is serotonin syndrome, and secondaries include the pre-existing conditions and other possibilities from the differential.

Let me look at the vignette again. "He felt his legs were stiff and heavy, couldn't really move them, toes retching turning inwards." This could be dystonia. So maybe acute dystonia is a possibility. But the clonus and tremors suggest serotonin syndrome more broadly.

In DSM-5-TR, medication-induced acute dystonia is coded as F24 (Drug-induced acute dystonia), but that's for antipsychotics. For SSRIs, it might be under other.

Actually, for coding, serotonin syndrome might not have a specific F-code. In ICD-10, it's T43.205A. But the instruction says to use F-codes. So perhaps for psychiatric purposes, it's classified under F06.8 as a mental disorder due to another medical condition (the medication effect).

Similarly, for dystonia, it could be F24.9.

Given that, perhaps the list:
1. Medication-Induced Serotonin Syndrome – F06.8
2. Autism Spectrum Disorder – F84.0
3. Major Depressive Disorder, Single Episode – F32.9
4. Medication-Induced Acute Dystonia – F24.9
5. Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (rule-out) – F06.8

But including NMS as a diagnosis when it's less likely might not be accurate. The vignette doesn't support it strongly.

Perhaps instead, include "Other specified anxiety disorder" or "Unspecified catatonia." But let's see the symptoms: vital signs show hypertension, which is autonomic instability, common in serotonin syndrome and NMS. But no fever mentioned, so NMS less likely.

Another thought: Could it be a hypertensive urgency causing encephalopathy? But neurological exam shows focal signs like clonus, not typical.

I think I should stick with the most apparent. So:
Primary: Serotonin Syndrome – F06.8
Then: Autism Spectrum Disorder – F84.0
Major Depressive Disorder – F32.9
Other specified medication-induced movement disorder – F19.99 (if not serotonin syndrome specifically)
Unspecified catatonia – F06.1

But catatonia requires certain criteria, and I'm not sure if met.

Perhaps list the chronic conditions and then other acute differentials. The instruction says "top 5 most likely," so include the acute issue and the chronic ones, and then other possible acute issues that are less likely.

Given the time constraint, I'll proceed with what seems most clinically sound.

column2:
We present an 18-year-old female with a past medical history of pediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorders associated with streptococcal infections (PANDAS), chronic insomnia, and schizophrenia who presented to the outpatient adult neurology office. Her childhood was notable for extensive verbal abuse and neglect from her mother, leading to untreated trauma. Three months prior to this visit, the patient was admitted to an inpatient psychiatric facility due to a 9-month history of persecutory delusions, auditory hallucinations, and blunted affect. She was diagnosed with paranoid-subtype schizophrenia and started on Haloperidol 5 mg twice a day. During her stay at the inpatient facility, she had multiple epileptic episodes; she was diagnosed with epilepsy and prescribed Lamotrigine. She initially started a dose of 25 mg once a day for 2 weeks and gradually increased to 50 mg once a day.

The patient scheduled the initial appointment for the chief concern of tremor. She described it as bilateral, occurring at rest and with action, and starting days after beginning Haloperidol. She described her schizophrenia as being well-controlled with the haloperidol and found the medication effective. Her vitals were within normal limits. Her physical exam was benign and only significant for akathisia and blunted affect. Specifically, on a neurological exam, she had intact cranial nerves I–XII, no focal sensory deficits, no motor strength deficits, and symmetric 2+/4+ deep tendon reflexes. Given the context, the tremor was likely an extrapyramidal side effect of Haloperidol. We consulted psychiatry, who recommended either decreasing the dose of haloperidol or switching to a second-generation atypical antipsychotic. The patient preferred to continue taking Haloperidol so we decreased her dose to 3 mg twice a day.

During the same visit, the patient expressed concern that her Lamotrogine dose was “not helping” her seizures. She described her seizures as starting at the age of eight. The seizures usually occurred after stressful situations involving the patient's mother. During the episodes, the patient loses motor control and falls to the ground with bilateral arm and limb shaking. She remains conscious during the episodes. Her uncle, present at the initial visit, described the episodes similarly and relayed that she kept her eyes closed and shook her head throughout the episodes. She did not bite her tongue, express incontinence, or have postictal confusion. Most lasted between “2–4 minutes.”

Even with the antiepileptic medication, the seizures continued to occur “every few weeks.” The patient was never treated for epilepsy before her inpatient stay 6 months ago. Since this visit focused on the patient's tremor, she was scheduled for a follow-up in a week regarding her seizures and told to continue to take the medications and call if she had another episode. She was also prescribed orders to draw routine labs.
column3: Psychogenic Nonepileptic Seizures (PNES)
column5:
Hmm, this is a complex case requiring careful analysis. The patient has multiple documented conditions and presenting symptoms. Let me start by extracting key clinical details systematically.

First, the patient is an 18-year-old female with a history of PANDAS, chronic insomnia, and previously diagnosed schizophrenia. There's childhood trauma involving verbal abuse and neglect. She was recently hospitalized for psychotic symptoms and started on haloperidol. Now she presents with tremor likely from medication, and ongoing seizure-like episodes.

Looking at the seizure descriptions: they're triggered by stress related to her mother, she remains conscious during episodes, no tongue biting or incontinence, and episodes last 2-4 minutes. These features strongly suggest psychogenic nonepileptic seizures rather than epileptic seizures. The DSM-5-TR would classify this as Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder.

For the primary diagnosis, I need to consider the most disabling current condition. The seizure episodes are clearly causing significant impairment and are the focus of current concern, so F44.5 makes sense as primary.

The schizophrenia diagnosis seems well-established with documented psychotic symptoms, but it's reportedly controlled on medication. PANDAS is relevant but not a current active concern. The childhood trauma likely contributes to current symptoms but isn't the primary issue.

Medication side effects are clearly present but are treatment complications rather than primary diagnoses. Chronic insomnia is historical but not elaborated in current presentation.

So the list should prioritize the most impactful current conditions while including relevant historical and comorbid diagnoses.
column6:
1. Functional Neurological Symptom Disorder (Conversion Disorder), with attacks or seizures - ICD-10 F44.5
2. Schizophrenia - ICD-10 F20.9
3. Medication-Induced Movement Disorder (Neuroleptic-Induced Parkinsonism) - ICD-10 G21.11
4. Unspecified Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorder - ICD-10 F43.9
5. Other Specified Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorder (PANDAS) - ICD-10 F42.8

column2: A 12-year-old girl presented with an acute onset of a 1month history of recurrent undesired and intrusive thoughts demanding her to repeat or stop doing certain behaviors to prevent unrelated danger (killing herself or going out in the street). She has stopped eating. The family frequently visited the emergency room (ER) to administer intravenous (IV) fluids. She started dressing and redressing for around 1 hr, repeated washing for around 1 hr, crossing her hands and scratching the wall, and crying and fearing killing herself or going out in the street. Family history: living with her mother. Her father passed away 2 years before presentation due to a medical illness. There is no history of mental illness in the family. She was doing well in school but had frequent absences in the last month before the presentation. Pregnancy, birth, and early development are unremarkable. Medical history: in this initial visit, the family denied the patient had any medical illnesses. The impression was that the patient had OCD. The treatment was SSRI and cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). However, because of the acute onset and severity of her symptoms, the patient was reevaluated in follow-up with consideration of possible pediatric acute neuropsychiatric syndrome. She reported that she had recurrent tonsillitis in the last year before presentation, and her last infection was just before the start of her symptoms. Her recurrent tonsillitis was severe to the extent that a tonsillectomy was advised 6-month ago. The obsessive thoughts were associated with symptoms of separation anxiety, being forgetful, and abnormal sensations (tingling sensation) in her palms and feet. She repeats wearing her shoes because of these abnormal sensations.
column3: Pediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorder associated with streptococcal infections (PANDAS)
column5:
Hmm, this is a complex pediatric psychiatric case with evolving symptoms. The user provides a detailed vignette and expects a diagnosis list following specific formatting. 

The key elements are: 12-year-old girl, acute onset of OCD-like symptoms (intrusive thoughts, compulsions), refusal to eat leading to ER visits, plus later reported tonsillitis history and neuropsychiatric symptoms (tingling sensations, forgetfulness). The initial OCD diagnosis was reconsidered due to acute onset and infection history.

For primary diagnosis, Pediatric Acute Neuropsychiatric Syndrome (PANS) fits best given the acute symptom onset following infection, OCD symptoms plus neurological symptoms. OCD remains secondary given symptom prominence. Separation anxiety is clearly documented. The refusal to eat and weight loss suggest avoidant/restrictive food intake. Tic disorder is considered due to repetitive movements though not explicitly labeled as tics.

The F-codes need to match DSM-5-TR classifications: PANS would fall under unspecified obsessive-compulsive disorder code since it's not separately coded. The food avoidance and tic codes are chosen conservatively based on described behaviors.

column2:
A 44-year-old female patient, without a personal or family history of psychiatric illness, was admitted to a psychiatric ward for a psychotic episode which has started three days before, characterized by perplexity, self-referent and mystical delusions, irritability, disorganized behavior, and aggressiveness, that had emerged shortly after a cluster of nocturnal GTC seizures. Neither Schneider's first-rank symptoms nor negative symptoms of schizophrenia were present. Additionally, some degree of mental confusion with temporal disorientation, as well as sustained, divided attention and memory deficits were noticed during psychiatric hospitalization. Past medical history was relevant for epilepsy since her early thirties, which had developed after a moderate-to-severe traumatic brain injury (TBI). She did not regularly attend follow-up neurology appointments and had poor adherence to antiepileptic treatment. Ancillary tests undergone during a previous hospitalization in a neurology ward (seven years before the hospitalization in psychiatry) had documented a focal slowing activity in the left frontotemporal topography on electroencephalogram (EEG) and a right cortico-subcortical parietooccipital lesion of encephalomalacia on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Additionally, she presented an amnestic mild cognitive impairment, possibly secondary to both the poorly controlled epilepsy and the prior TBI.

During the hospitalization in the psychiatric ward for the index psychotic episode, haematological and biochemical screening, thyroid function, folic acid, and cyanocobalamin were normal, serologies for VDRL, HIV, and B and C hepatitis were negative, and valproic acid levels were subtherapeutic.
column3: Postictal psychosis
column5:
Hmm, this is a complex clinical vignette requiring careful analysis. The patient presents with acute psychosis following seizures, with a history of traumatic brain injury and poorly controlled epilepsy. Need to prioritize diagnoses most consistent with the temporal relationship between seizures and psychosis onset, along with the documented neurological findings.

The key features are the post-ictal timing, confusion symptoms, and clear neurological etiology. Primary diagnosis should reflect the direct causative relationship. Secondary diagnoses need to account for the underlying conditions contributing to the presentation.

Considering DSM-5-TR categories, the psychotic disorder due to another medical condition fits best as primary. The epilepsy history warrants its own diagnosis given its role in the presentation. The cognitive impairment and TBI sequelae should be included as they're documented contributors. The seizure disorder itself isn't a psychiatric diagnosis per F-code requirements, so focusing on the psychiatric manifestations.

For coding accuracy: F06.0 covers psychosis due to epilepsy, F06.7 covers the mild neurocognitive disorder, and F07.0 covers personality changes from TBI. The epilepsy diagnosis should use the unspecified code since no specific seizure type is detailed in psychiatric terms. The mild cognitive impairment fits the amnestic specifier.

2. Epilepsy - ICD-10 F80.8
3. Mild Neurocognitive Disorder Due to Traumatic Brain Injury, With Behavioral Disturbance - ICD-10 F06.7
4. Personality Change Due to Traumatic Brain Injury, Aggressive Type - ICD-10 F07.0
5. Delirium - ICD-10 F05

column2:
J is a mid-20s military service member living independently in the community with a partner. J has a history of multiple ACEs (ACE scale score of 10/10), with caregivers that were both physically and emotionally abusive when J's needs were voiced, resulting in a belief that it was unacceptable, unsafe, and futile to resolve interpersonal problems with caregivers, thus creating a sense of powerlessness and helplessness. Child and family services were never involved, and no legal charges were ever laid against the family for the abuse that J endured. J struggled with containing anger since early childhood resulting in physical and verbal aggression towards peers and teachers at school and family members at home. Caregivers attempted to contain J's aggressive behavior through forced administration of psychiatric medication. While growing up, J feared others and preferred to be alone, despite longing for family and friends. Socialization with peers proved difficult, as J was easily overwhelmed by noise associated with social contact and was frequently ridiculed or misunderstood while trying to verbally communicate.

As a young adult, J left family to enter the military, which became an immediate source of attachment and social belonging. More recently, J became increasingly unable to cope with anger following an ill-suited work position and a musculoskeletal injury, resulting in frequent angry verbal altercations and threats of violence towards military peers who placed restrictions on his activities. This led to disciplinary action and isolation from the unit, which further increased anger, hopelessness, and suicidal thoughts and led to a psychiatric military assessment. During the assessment, J disclosed feelings of intense anger which eventually manifested in an attack on a family member in an amnestic dissociated state. J's history indicated that pharmacological treatments had either been ineffective or caused significant side effects. The military psychiatrist determined J ought to be considered for military discharge. This triggered flashbacks of past childhood abuse and a significant increase in rage. J refused trials of psychiatric medications in the community due to a childhood history of forced medication administration. Due to significant safety concerns and limited ability to control aggressive behavior in the community, J's military psychiatrist referred J for an inpatient admission.

On initial assessment for admission, J appeared distrustful, angry, and concerned about acting out on anger and expressed suicidal ideation. On mental status examination, J was tall and appeared neatly dressed in a military uniform. J appeared hypervigilant and intensely watchful and was well spoken, using a “sharp” tone of voice. J provided a detailed history, demonstrating a goal-directed thought form and a high level of abstract thinking, logical analysis, and good recall. There were no delusions or hallucinations, but J endorsed prominent active suicidal ideation, with intent to act upon these thoughts if not hospitalized; however, there were no immediate, specific suicide plans.
column3: Autism Spectrum Disorder, Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), Unspecified Anxiety Disorder, and Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)
column5:
Hmm, this is a complex clinical vignette requiring careful analysis. The patient J has a history of severe childhood trauma, chronic anger issues, and current suicidal ideation with intent. Need to extract key symptoms systematically while considering diagnostic criteria.

The ACE score of 10/10 indicates profound childhood adversity. The chronic anger and aggression since childhood, combined with interpersonal difficulties and hypervigilance, point toward trauma-related disorders. The dissociative amnesia during the attack on a family member is particularly significant.

Noticing the pattern of attachment to military as replacement family, then decompensation after injury and disciplinary action. The refusal of medication due to forced administration history adds complexity. Mental status shows organized thought but severe safety concerns.

For differential: PTSD seems primary given trauma history, re-experiencing (flashbacks), avoidance (of medication/interpersonal trust), negative alterations in cognition/mood, and arousal (anger/hypervigilance). The dissociative episode supports this. Borderline personality disorder is strong secondary consideration due to chronic anger, unstable relationships, identity disturbance (military as attachment), and suicidal behavior. Intermittent explosive disorder fits the aggressive outbursts. Persistent depressive disorder may underlie chronic hopelessness. Adjustment disorder could explain recent worsening but seems less specific than other diagnoses.

Must ensure each diagnosis aligns with DSM-5-TR criteria based only on provided information, not assumptions. The suicidal intent with hospitalization need elevates acuity across diagnoses.

5. Adjustment Disorder with Mixed Disturbance of Emotions and Conduct - ICD-10 F43.25

column2:
Our patient was a 41-year-old man with diagnoses of schizoaffective disorder and polysubstance use disorder who was admitted to the inpatient psychiatry unit after an extended stay (24 days) in the psychiatric emergency department, where he presented with manic and psychotic symptoms, including mood lability, pressured speech, grandiosity, paranoia, and disorganized thinking, in the context of medication noncompliance and elopement from his group home. His prolonged psychiatric emergency department course was due to difficulty finding an available inpatient psychiatric bed at or within a reasonable radius of the receiving hospital. Per the patient's guardian, medications confirmed 6 weeks prior to admission included divalproex extended-release (ER) 500 mg twice daily, clonazepam 0.5 mg twice daily, risperidone 4 mg twice daily, risperidone microspheres long-acting injection 25 mg every 2 weeks, quetiapine 400 mg daily, and trazodone 100 mg daily. Based on the fill history and patient report, nonadherence was likely in the weeks prior to admission.

Limited information was available regarding the patient's past psychiatric history, as he was a difficult historian due to his mental state at the time of the initial assessment, as noted above. From a review of available records, he was noted to have been diagnosed with schizoaffective disorder in his early twenties and to have been prescribed multiple medications at various points to address manic and psychotic symptoms, including risperidone (up to 8 mg per day of the oral form and up to 25 mg every 14 days of the long-acting injectable form), quetiapine (up to 400 mg per day), and divalproex (up to 1500 mg per day). He was also prescribed trazodone for sleep (up to 50 mg per day) and sertraline for anxiety (unclear dose and duration per records). A note was made of at least partial response to risperidone and divalproex for manic and psychotic symptoms, though the durability of these effects was difficult to assess due to poor compliance. Records documented a history of over 30 psychiatric hospitalizations, usually in the setting of medication noncompliance leading to symptom relapse, with two such hospitalizations in the year prior to presentation. Mention was also made of a suicide attempt three years prior to the presentation, though the circumstances of this were unclear (the patient had reported this to an emergency room provider at an outside hospital; he denied any such history on evaluation in our psychiatric emergency room).

A history of “semi-regular” use of alcohol and cannabis was also noted in his records, beginning in his early twenties, though specific amounts, frequency, adverse consequences, and any treatment for substance use were not documented. Notably, his urine toxicology screen was negative at the time of presentation to our psychiatric emergency room.

Medically, a history of acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) (for which the patient had refused treatment with medications) was noted, with the last documented CD4 count being in the 430s range at an outside hospital one year prior to presentation.

Family history was significant for schizophrenia and suicide in a maternal uncle. In terms of social history, records indicated that the patient was an only child and that his parents separated when he was an infant; he was noted to have had no relationship with his father. He reported no history of domestic or family conflicts but also noted no current social support at the time of presentation. There was no documented history of his experiencing physical or sexual abuse, though he referred in a prior emergency room visit to a history of “verbal abuse” (unclear how long ago or by whom). He was also noted to have been married in the past but separated for 20 years prior to the presentation; he had no children. He was noted to have lived in numerous group homes over the prior ten years due to mental health issues, with frequent periods of homelessness between these stays, including for three days prior to presentation after he had absconded from his last group home due to paranoid concerns about the staff and residents there. Educationally, he was noted to have completed high school and college but to have been unemployed for ten years prior to presentation, receiving disability income, and having a guardian appointed to him due to mental health issues.

Physical examination upon initial presentation in the psychiatric emergency room was unremarkable other than the patient appearing disheveled, irritable, and guarded. Vital signs were within normal limits. Laboratory tests, including electrolytes, liver function tests, complete blood count, thyroid function tests, urine analysis, and urine drug screen, were all within normal limits.

On mental status examination, he showed loud, pressured speech, guarded and labile affect, irritable and elevated mood, disorganized (tangential, loose) thinking, paranoid delusions that staff and residents at the group home where he had been living were involved in a conspiracy against him, no reported suicidal or homicidal ideation, and poor insight (e.g., denying that he had any mental health issues and that he only needed sertraline to “clear his head”).
column3: Treatment-refractory schizoaffective disorder
column5:
Hmm, this is a complex clinical vignette requiring careful analysis. The patient presents with clear manic and psychotic symptoms, but there are multiple layers to consider. 

First, I need to extract all relevant clinical data systematically. The patient has a long history of schizoaffective disorder diagnosis with recurrent hospitalizations, current manic psychosis with pressured speech, grandiosity, paranoia, and disorganization. Key factors include medication nonadherence, substance use history (though currently negative tox screen), and significant psychosocial stressors like homelessness. 

For diagnostic reasoning, the core issue is differentiating schizoaffective disorder from other psychotic and mood disorders. The chronic course with recurrent psychotic and mood episodes, poor inter-episode recovery, and absence of substance-induced symptoms currently support schizoaffective disorder as primary. The polysubstance use disorder is clearly documented but appears in remission currently. The personality disorder consideration arises from chronic interpersonal difficulties and instability across multiple domains. 

The AIDS diagnosis with treatment refusal is notable but doesn't directly explain the psychiatric presentation. The negative physical exam and labs rule out acute medical causes. The family history of schizophrenia strengthens the psychotic disorder diagnosis. 

I'll prioritize schizoaffective disorder as primary given the diagnostic history and current mixed psychotic/manic presentation. The other diagnoses follow logically from the documented history and current presentation.

column2: An 82-year old married female from Hindu nuclear family with history of Alzheimer's dementia in first degree relative, was treated for depression 9 months prior presentation on the outpatient basis. She remitted after 2 months and antidepressant was continued for 7 months, till 1 month prior to this episode. There was no history of forgetfulness or other features of dementia, substance use or any chronic medical illness. She presented with persistent elevated mood, marked feeling of well-being, talkativeness, overspending, increased appetite, increased energy, and overactivity for 10 days. In her 9th decade, she would walk briskly to a temple at the top of a mountain which was not her usual self. She was not aggressive or hostile. Four days prior admission, she was found to be confused, not recognizing place and person, and was unaware of time. She stopped self-care, would pass urine and stool in places other than the toilet, would not drink water saying it was mixed with poison and mumble to herself. She was unable to concentrate, was restless, and would not sleep at night. She was aggressive at times, ran out of the house naked, and had to be physically restrained. When brought to hospital, she was agitated, incoherent, and had to be kept in 4-point restraint. There was stupor and echolalia but no other signs of catatonia. The physical examination was within normal limits except tachycardia. There was spontaneous movement and pupils were normal but other neurological examination could not be completed due to uncooperativeness and agitation. On mental state examination, orientation was impaired to time, place, and person, attention and concentration could be aroused but ill-sustained, speech rate was increased with flight of ideas, affect was irritable, and delusion of grandiosity was present. The investigations including basic blood parameters, urine routine examination and culture, thyroid function test, calcium, albumin, magnesium, vitamin-B12, and vitamin-D were within normal range. The DRS-R-98 score was 20 with YMRS score of 22 and BFCRS score of 5.
column3: Delirious mania
column5:
Hmm, this is a complex clinical case requiring careful analysis. The patient is an 82-year-old female with a history of depression and family history of Alzheimer's dementia, now presenting with acute behavioral changes. 

The key features I need to consider are: the sudden onset of elevated mood and behavioral symptoms lasting 10 days, followed by rapid deterioration with confusion, disorientation, and psychotic features. The normal lab results rule out common medical causes, and the assessment scores point toward mixed features of mania and cognitive impairment.

For differential diagnosis, the acute onset with mood elevation preceding cognitive decline strongly suggests a manic episode due to bipolar disorder, especially given her history of depression. However, the rapid cognitive decline and late age of onset make me consider secondary causes like delirium, though lab results don't support typical medical causes. 

The possibility of neurocognitive disorder with behavioral disturbance is important given her age and family history, but the acute manic-like presentation is unusual for typical dementia progression. Schizoaffective disorder could explain the mixed mood and psychotic symptoms, while brief psychotic disorder might account for the sudden onset but doesn't fully capture the mood component.

I need to prioritize based on symptom patterns and timelines. The clear manic symptoms preceding cognitive changes point most strongly toward bipolar disorder as primary, with other conditions considered based on specific features of the presentation.

4. Schizoaffective Disorder, Bipolar Type - ICD-10 F25.0
5. Brief Psychotic Disorder - ICD-10 F23

column2:
A 25-year-old female with a history of schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type, at 20 weeks of pregnancy, presented with psychosis and catatonia in the setting of medication nonadherence. She was at her obstetrics (OB)/gynecology appointment when the provider noticed her bizarre behavior and agitation. They recommended that her father take her to the emergency department (ED) for an evaluation. In the ED, the patient was disorganized and endorsed hallucinations, both auditory and visual. She was agitated and resistant to medical care. Her father petitioned for involuntary inpatient psychiatric admission, given the severity of her psychosis.

Patient had a history of multiple inpatient psychiatric hospitalizations since childhood, including a suicide attempt via overdose approximately 2 years prior to presentation. Her last inpatient psychiatric hospitalization was approximately 1 year prior to presentation, where she was stabilized on paliperidone palmitate and lithium. At discharge, the patient moved outside of the United States with her husband and discontinued her psychotropic medications. Patient returned to the United States 1 month prior to admission to give birth in the United States. Her condition acutely worsened during the week leading to admission.
column3: Catatonia associated with schizoaffective disorder
column5:
Hmm, this is a complex clinical case requiring careful diagnostic reasoning. The patient has a known history of schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type, and is currently pregnant with acute psychosis and catatonia following medication discontinuation. 

The key elements to consider are the pre-existing diagnosis, the acute exacerbation with mood and psychotic features, the presence of catatonia, and the context of pregnancy and medication nonadherence. The history of multiple hospitalizations and prior suicide attempt adds to the complexity.

For the primary diagnosis, schizoaffective disorder, bipolar type, seems most appropriate given the chronic history and current presentation with both mood and psychotic symptoms. The catatonia specifier should be included due to the noted catatonic features. 

Secondary diagnoses should account for the acute exacerbation, the catatonic features as a separate specifiable condition, and any relevant substance or medical factors. However, no substance use is mentioned, and pregnancy-related conditions need to be considered but aren't primary psychiatric diagnoses per the instructions.

The differential should include other psychotic and mood disorders but schizoaffective disorder best fits the longitudinal course and current symptoms. Catatonia needs to be specified separately as it's a modifier. The medication nonadherence and pregnancy are contextual factors rather than separate diagnoses.

4. Bipolar I Disorder, With Psychotic Features - ICD-10 F31.2

column2: Ms. T is a 34-year-old female with no significant past psychiatric history. She presented to the emergency department due to one month of worsening mood, inability to care for herself, hyperreligiosity, auditory hallucinations, and perseveration on the idea that she is going to hell. The patient reported auditory hallucinations in which she heard the voices of Satan or Saints. She reported anergia, amotivation, anhedonia, decreased appetite, and difficulty falling and staying asleep. The patient also had new-onset superficial cutting of her wrists. She was perseverating on the idea that she had become an apostate and was therefore going to hell. The patient denied suicidal ideation, homicidal ideation, or visual hallucinations. The patient's family history was relevant for a maternal grandmother with schizophrenia. After evaluation in the emergency department, acute inpatient psychiatric hospitalization was recommended. Ms. T signed herself into the psychiatric hospital voluntarily for her first hospitalization. The patient's parents reported that this behavior was unusual and abrupt and that she was previously sociable and well-liked by her peers. The patient's symptoms started within 3 weeks of the patient contracting COVID-19 which was confirmed via PCR. They deny any similar symptoms or similar behavior in the past. Her parents report that the patient had taken a leave of absence from work as she was frequently calling them from work crying. They report that the patient's speech was childlike, as if she had regressed.
column3: Major depressive disorder, recurrent, severe with psychotic features
column5:
Hmm, this is a complex clinical case requiring careful analysis. The patient presents with a mix of psychotic, mood, and behavioral symptoms following a COVID-19 infection. 

The key features include auditory hallucinations (Satan/Saints voices), hyperreligiosity, delusions about going to hell, self-harm behavior, depressive symptoms (anhedonia, sleep/appetite issues), and apparent regression to childlike speech. The acute onset post-COVID and family history of schizophrenia are particularly notable.

For the primary diagnosis, the psychotic symptoms with religious content and hallucinations point toward a psychotic disorder, but the temporal link to COVID infection and absence of prior episodes make Brief Psychotic Disorder most fitting. The depressive symptoms are significant but appear secondary to the psychotic process.

The differential needs to account for the mood component (hence Bipolar I with psychotic features), the possibility of a primary depressive disorder with psychotic features, and the potential for this to be the first episode of schizophrenia given family history. The stressor of COVID infection also warrants adjustment disorder consideration, though the severity exceeds typical adjustment reactions.

The F-codes must precisely match the diagnostic specifiers: F23 for brief psychotic disorder, F31.64 for bipolar with current mixed features, etc. Each code should reflect the most specific clinical presentation described.

column2:
A 44-year-old Caucasian female was referred to our department of psychiatry by her neurosurgeon, after having been operated on a pituitary macroadenoma compressing the optic chiasm, for visual hallucinations.

She was married. She had no prior psychiatric history. She did not take any medication that could produce hallucinations.

On March 2019, the patient underwent transsphenoidal adenomectomy.

In the first postoperative day, the patient reported the persistence of visual hallucinations and was referred to our department of psychiatry one week later.

Upon arrival to our department, the patient was cooperative, did not verbalize delirium, and had no cognitive impairment. She reported visual hallucinations. These hallucinations appeared several times a day for variable periods of time and lasted a few minutes. They caused anxiety and insomnia. The patient reported that she was embarrassed by these hallucinations. She saw unfamiliar human faces with no other associated signs. These images did not speak, and the patient knew that the hallucinations were unreal.

The neurologic exam revealed no abnormalities. Her Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score was 28.
column3: Charles Bonnet syndrome
column5:
Hmm, this is a complex psychiatric case requiring careful analysis. The patient presents with visual hallucinations following pituitary macroadenoma surgery, which immediately suggests an organic etiology. 

The key features are: new-onset visual hallucinations post-neurosurgery, intact reality testing (knows they're unreal), preserved cognition (MMSE 28), no delirium, and significant distress causing anxiety and insomnia. The hallucinations are simple (faces) without auditory components.

The absence of prior psychiatric history, medication effects, or neurological abnormalities on exam makes primary psychotic disorders less likely. Given the clear temporal relationship to brain surgery, a neurocognitive disorder due to another medical condition seems most plausible. 

Charles Bonnet syndrome comes to mind given isolated complex visual hallucinations with insight, though typically associated with visual pathway lesions rather than pituitary issues. However, the surgical compression of optic chiasm provides a plausible anatomical basis.

Secondary diagnoses should consider other conditions that could explain hallucinations without delirium or cognitive impairment. Substance-induced is unlikely without relevant history. PTSD could be considered given traumatic surgery. Unspecified psychotic disorder might capture residual symptoms if organic cause isn't fully established. Adjustment disorder accounts for the distress from both illness and hallucinations.

The primary diagnosis should reflect the most direct causal link between the brain surgery and hallucinations while accounting for preserved cognition. The differential needs to cover both organic and psychiatric possibilities while prioritizing based on clinical evidence.
column6:
1. Psychotic Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition, With Hallucinations (Pituitary Macroadenoma, Status Post Transsphenoidal Adenomectomy) - ICD-10 F06.0
2. Unspecified Psychotic Disorder - ICD-10 F29
3. Adjustment Disorder With Mixed Anxiety and Depressed Mood - ICD-10 F43.23
4. Unspecified Neurocognitive Disorder - ICD-10 F09
5. Unspecified Anxiety Disorder - ICD-10 F41.9

column2:
A young man was referred by his Veterans Affairs (VA) primary care provider to the outpatient mental health clinic due to concerns for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and depression. He served in the military for 4 years, including a 6-month tour in Iraq. While in Iraq he worked as an assault vehicle operator and was involved in frequent foot patrols. He reported numerous traumatic experiences, including frequent receipt of incoming fire, multiple ambushes, and an explosion by an improvised explosive device (IED) that injured several fellow soldiers.

He denied any psychiatric issues prior to his military service, but reported that since returning home “there ain’t a day that goes by that I don’t think about [these experiences].” The thoughts were highly distressing and he had frequent violent nightmares. He reported intense guilt relating to the belief that he should have detected the IED and been able to protect his colleagues. He reported a number of triggers (eg, walking down a city street; driving by a shooting range) that reminded him of his experiences in Iraq and induced panic-like symptoms (eg, fear, anxiety, racing heart, and feeling shaky). He avoided things that reminded him of these events and was reluctant to discuss his history.

He felt numb and withdrawn from others, reported difficulty sleeping, and was always “on guard.” He startled easily and had angry outbursts. The patient was hopeless at times, but denied suicidal thoughts. He reported difficulty concentrating and had significant fluctuations in his weight. He denied mania, psychosis, or medical problems. He reported drinking more than 12 beers 2 to 3 times per week. He denied any other substance abuse history.

The patient was briefly in outpatient treatment while he was still in the military. He was prescribed a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) but did not find it helpful and so he discontinued it. He was referred for psychotherapy but did not keep his appointments.

The patient grew up in the suburb of a small city. Though the patient initially described his childhood as “great,” later data revealed a history of early traumatic experiences.
column3: Posttraumatic stress disorder requiring therapy
column5:
First, I need to accurately diagnose based on the clinical case vignette provided. I must follow the DSM-5-TR criteria and only use the information given. The response should be a structured list of the top 5 most likely diagnoses with ICD-10 F-codes, starting with the primary diagnosis followed by four secondary diagnoses. I should not include any clinical reasoning in the output, just the list.

Let me extract and organize the key clinical information from the vignette to support my diagnostic reasoning, as per the rubric.

**Key Clinical Details:**

- Patient: Young man, military veteran with a tour in Iraq.

- Traumatic experiences: Frequent incoming fire, ambushes, IED explosion injuring fellow soldiers.

- Core symptoms:

  - Distressing thoughts about experiences daily.

  - Violent nightmares.

  - Intense guilt related to IED incident.

  - Triggers (e.g., city streets, shooting ranges) causing panic-like symptoms (fear, anxiety, racing heart, shakiness).

  - Avoidance of reminders.

  - Reluctance to discuss history.

  - Numbness and withdrawal from others.

  - Difficulty sleeping.

  - Always "on guard" – hypervigilance.

  - Startles easily.

  - Angry outbursts.

  - Hopelessness at times but denies suicidal thoughts.

  - Difficulty concentrating.

  - Significant weight fluctuations.

- Denies mania, psychosis, or medical problems.

- Substance use: Drinks more than 12 beers 2-3 times per week, denies other substance abuse.

- Treatment history: Previously prescribed SSRI, found unhelpful, discontinued. Referred for psychotherapy but did not keep appointments.

- Childhood: Initially described as "great," but later data reveals early traumatic experiences (though specifics not detailed).

**Organizing Symptoms for DSM-5-TR Diagnoses:**

1. **Posttraumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD):** The vignette strongly suggests PTSD. Symptoms include:

   - Exposure to traumatic events (Criterion A): Military combat experiences.

   - Intrusive symptoms (Criterion B): Distressing thoughts, nightmares.

   - Avoidance (Criterion C): Avoiding reminders, reluctance to discuss.

   - Negative alterations in cognition and mood (Criterion D): Guilt, numbness, withdrawal, negative emotional state.

   - Alterations in arousal and reactivity (Criterion E): Hypervigilance, startle response, angry outbursts, difficulty sleeping, concentration issues.

   - Duration more than a month, and causes distress or impairment.

2. **Major Depressive Disorder (MDD):** Symptoms like hopelessness, difficulty concentrating, weight fluctuations, sleep disturbance, and possibly anhedonia (numbness, withdrawal) could indicate depression. However, many symptoms overlap with PTSD. The vignette mentions concerns for depression, and he has depressive symptoms.

3. **Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD):** He drinks more than 12 beers 2-3 times per week. This could qualify as hazardous use. DSM-5-TR criteria for AUD include drinking in larger amounts or over longer periods than intended, among others. With more than 12 beers per session, 2-3 times a week, this might meet criteria for moderate to severe AUD, depending on other factors like impairment.

4. **Other Specified Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorder:** If PTSD criteria aren't fully met, but there are trauma-related symptoms, this could be considered. However, from the vignette, PTSD seems highly likely.

5. **Adjustment Disorder:** But with chronic symptoms since returning from service, PTSD is more appropriate.

6. **Anxiety Disorders:** Panic-like symptoms triggered by reminders, but these are part of PTSD.

7. **Personality Disorders or Other Conditions:** Not enough information; childhood trauma might suggest complex PTSD or other issues, but DSM-5-TR doesn't have complex PTSD as a separate diagnosis; it's under PTSD.

**Prioritizing Diagnoses:**

- Primary: PTSD is the most salient, given the referral reason and symptom cluster.

- Secondary: Major Depressive Disorder often co-occurs with PTSD.

- Secondary: Alcohol Use Disorder, as substance use is common in veterans with PTSD.

column2:
A 20-year-old woman was referred by her family physician to a community mental health team in London, United Kingdom. Her mental state had deteriorated progressively over the previous 12 months, following the death of her father. After a period living alone, she had returned to the family home 4 months prior to her presentation and had been noted to be socially withdrawn, preoccupied, and distractible. Her family physician, suspecting a depressive episode, had prescribed citalopram up to a dosage of 40 mg once daily, to no effect. Her family subsequently sought advice from the family physician when the patient was noted to be speaking to herself, expressing concerns about people meaning her harm, and professing the belief that she could hear other peoples’ thoughts.

The patient had been born in Sierra Leone after a complicated delivery and had traveled to the United Kingdom as a child with her family, who were fleeing from a civil war. On arrival in the United Kingdom, her family claimed asylum and moved into a small apartment in a high-rise building in central London. Although there was no reported developmental delay, she had struggled academically at school and was bullied for having overweight. She left school without qualifications at age 16 years and worked as a shop assistant. She left this job about a year prior to her referral to psychiatry after a period of sick leave following the death of her father. She was a nonsmoker, did not drink alcohol, and denied illicit drug use. A paternal relative was reported to have a diagnosis of schizophrenia. There was no comorbid physical illness.

On review, the patient was kempt and had overweight. Eye contact was fleeting, and she presented as anxious, with a degree of psychomotor agitation. Her speech was normal in rate, volume, and tone, although tangential. There was no other evidence of thought disorder. She denied feeling low in mood or suicidal and was objectively euthymic. There was some sleep disturbance, with the patient reporting being fearful to go to sleep owing to persecutory beliefs regarding her neighbors. She reflected that over the preceding few months, she had experienced a sensation of detachment from her immediate environment, as though it was not real, making her world similar to that of a video game. She reported that in the apartment where she had previously been living, she had realized that something was amiss and had become convinced that the door number of her neighbor’s flat, number 6, signified that they meant her harm. She explained this was because 6 was associated with the number of the devil. She reported hearing her neighbors commenting negatively about her appearance. These distressing experiences prompted her to return to her family home, but she continued to hear her neighbors’ voices making derogatory comments about her appearance and began to hear them commenting on her actions and thoughts in the third person as well. On returning home, her paranoia regarding her previous neighbors worsened, resulting in her rarely leaving the house. The volume and frequency of derogatory auditory hallucinations also worsened, and she reported hearing the thoughts of others as well. There was a degree of insight, and although the patient was convinced of the reality of her experiences, she also saw the stress of losing her father as associated with her experiences and was accepting of input from mental health services.
column3: Schizophrenia
column5:
Okay, let me start by carefully reading the clinical vignette to extract all relevant information. The patient is a 20-year-old woman with a 12-month progressive deterioration after her father's death. She has social withdrawal, preoccupation, distractibility, and no response to citalopram. Key symptoms include speaking to herself, persecutory delusions (neighbors meaning harm, door number 6 as devil-related), auditory hallucinations (derogatory comments, hearing others' thoughts), and tangential speech. Also mentions derealization (feeling detached, world like a video game). No mood symptoms, euthymic, some sleep disturbance due to paranoia. History includes traumatic migration, academic struggles, bullying, family history of schizophrenia. No substance use.

Hmm, need to organize this. Positive symptoms like delusions and hallucinations are prominent, negative symptoms like social withdrawal, and disorganized speech (tangential). Duration is 12 months with functional decline. No major mood episode, which rules out primary mood disorder with psychotic features. The lack of response to antidepressants and absence of depressive symptoms make depressive psychosis less likely.

Considering differentials. Primary diagnosis seems to be a psychotic disorder. Schizophrenia fits because of delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, negative symptoms, duration >6 months, and functional impairment. Schizoaffective is less likely since mood symptoms are absent. Brief psychotic disorder duration is too long. Schizophreniform would require less than 6 months, but here it's 12 months. Delusional disorder might be considered but auditory hallucinations are present, which isn't typical. PTSD could be possible given trauma history, but psychotic symptoms aren't core to PTSD unless with psychotic features. However, the derealization might point to PTSD or another trauma-related disorder. But the primary symptoms align more with schizophrenia.

Wait, the vignette mentions derealization ("detachment from her immediate environment"). Could that indicate depersonalization/derealization disorder? But it's in the context of psychosis, so probably secondary. Also, her insight is partial, which is common in schizophrenia. Family history of schizophrenia increases risk. No substance use rules out substance-induced psychosis.

So, primary diagnosis: Schizophrenia. Then secondary diagnoses: PTSD given trauma history (civil war, migration), but need to check if criteria are met. She has avoidance (rarely leaving house), negative alterations in cognition (paranoia), but does she have re-experiencing? Not explicitly mentioned. Still, possible. Other secondaries: Persistent depressive disorder? Not really, she's euthymic. Anxiety disorders? She's anxious but psychosis is primary. Body dysmorphic disorder? Unlikely. Delusional disorder if hallucinations aren't prominent, but they are. So maybe PTSD, then maybe other specified schizophrenia spectrum disorder if not full criteria? No, she meets schizophrenia criteria. Also, consider other psychotic disorders due to another medical condition, but no physical illness noted.

Need top 5 diagnoses. Primary: Schizophrenia. Secondary: PTSD, then maybe other trauma-related disorder. Also, adjustment disorder? But duration too long. Possibly other specified psychotic disorder? Not necessary. Let's list: 1. Schizophrenia, 2. PTSD, 3. Delusional Disorder (persecutory type) but since hallucinations present, maybe not. Actually, DSM-5 allows hallucinations if not prominent, but here they are prominent. So delusional disorder is less likely. 4. Brief psychotic disorder? No, duration too long. 5. Schizoaffective disorder? No mood episode. So maybe include other specified trauma disorder or unspecified psychosis. But better to stick with likely ones.

ICD-10 codes: Schizophrenia is F20.9. PTSD is F43.10 (or F43.1? Actually, ICD-10 is F43.1 for PTSD). Delusional disorder F22. Could also consider other nonaffective psychosis F28. But since she has derealization, maybe F48.1 for depersonalization-derealization disorder. However, that's not primary. So secondary diagnoses: PTSD, delusional disorder, other specified schizophrenia spectrum disorder, and maybe adjustment disorder? But adjustment disorder is within 3 months of stressor, here it's 12 months. So not that.

Given the trauma history, PTSD is plausible. Also, she has derealization, which could be part of PTSD. So secondary: PTSD. Next, maybe other specified psychotic disorder? But she meets schizophrenia criteria. Another secondary could be schizoaffective disorder, but no mood symptoms. So perhaps list delusional disorder as alternative if hallucinations are less prominent, but they are prominent. Actually, auditory hallucinations are key here, so schizophrenia is correct.

Wait, the vignette says "no other evidence of thought disorder" but speech is tangential, which is a thought disorder. So disorganized speech is present. Negative symptoms like withdrawal. Duration >6 months. So schizophrenia.

So final list: 1. Schizophrenia, 2. PTSD, 3. Delusional disorder, 4. Other specified schizophrenia spectrum disorder (if not full criteria, but she meets criteria), 5. Brief psychotic disorder? No. Maybe unspecified trauma disorder. Or acute stress disorder? But duration too long. Hmm.

Perhaps include other specified dissociative disorder due to derealization. But derealization here is likely part of psychosis. So maybe F44.89 for other specified dissociative disorder. But not sure.

Better to list the most likely differentials. So primary schizophrenia, then PTSD, then delusional disorder, then schizophreniform disorder (but duration too long), then other specified psychotic disorder. But schizophreniform is less than 6 months, so not applicable. So maybe include other specified trauma- and stressor-related disorder. Or adjustment disorder with mixed disturbance of emotions and conduct? But she has psychosis, so not.

Alternatively, consider substance-induced psychotic disorder, but no substance use. So ruled out.

Maybe include other specified dissociative disorder for derealization. Code F44.89. Yes, that could be third. Then delusional disorder fourth, and maybe other specified psychotic disorder fifth.

But need to prioritize based on likelihood. So after schizophrenia, PTSD is likely given trauma. Then delusional disorder as alternative psychosis. Then other specified dissociative disorder. Then maybe other specified psychotic disorder.

But DSM-5 has other specified schizophrenia spectrum disorder (F28). That could be if she doesn't meet full criteria, but she does. So not necessary.

Maybe include unspecified schizophrenia spectrum disorder? No.

Okay, let's list: 1. Schizophrenia, 2. PTSD, 3. Other specified dissociative disorder (derealization), 4. Delusional disorder, 5. Other specified psychotic disorder. But delusional disorder should be higher than dissociative disorder since psychosis is primary. So swap 3 and 4.

Also, check ICD-10 codes: Schizophrenia F20.9, PTSD F43.10, Delusional disorder F22, Other specified dissociative disorder F44.89, Other specified psychotic disorder F28. Yes.

But is other specified psychotic disorder needed? Might be redundant. Could include brief psychotic disorder? No, duration. So maybe keep it.

Alternatively, include adjustment disorder? But with psychotic features? Not typical. So better to stick with psychosis and trauma-related.

Thus, final list: 1. Schizophrenia F20.9, 2. Posttraumatic stress disorder F43.10, 3. Delusional disorder, persecutory type F22, 4. Other specified dissociative disorder F44.89, 5. Other specified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorder F28.

Yes, that seems comprehensive.

5. Other Specified Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorder - ICD-10 F28

column2:
A 29-year old man who is married and an employed Army veteran presented with headache from a mild traumatic brain injury (TBI) diagnosed before his Army discharge. He came to a Veterans Affairs hospital requesting buprenorphine/naloxone and complained of marital problems and job absenteeism. His TBI occurred when a roadside bomb overturned his supply truck in Afghanistan. He lost consciousness during the bombing and awoke with severe head and neck pain but no radiological brain, spine, or skull damage or focal neurological signs. He was given 20 oral morphine (5 mg) tablets and consumed them in 4 days rather than the intended 2 weeks. After finishing the morphine, he mitigated his pain with alcohol and ibuprofen (400-800 mg daily).

His opioid and ibuprofen use for TBI headaches escalated during and after his time in the military despite repeated efforts to stop by using clonidine, which relieved his withdrawal symptoms, although a rapid clonidine with naltrexone detoxification failed. After consuming a 6-week supply of morphine (5 mg) from his family physician in 3 weeks, he started receiving morphine from multiple pain physicians for about a year and buying prescription opioids from a friend. When the prescription opioids became too expensive, he started using heroin intravenously. After using heroin for about a year, he survived a respiratory arrest from overdosing with heroin mixed with fentanyl. This almost fatal overdose and persistent headaches scared him into going to a Veterans Affairs hospital, wanting buprenorphine/naloxone. His headaches had gotten worse since his injury 3 years ago, but new radiologic and neurologic examinations showed no abnormalities.
column3: Opioid use disorder and mild TBI
column5:
Hmm, this is a complex clinical vignette requiring careful analysis. The patient is a 29-year-old Army veteran with multiple overlapping issues: chronic pain from TBI, escalating opioid use transitioning to heroin, and significant functional impairment. 

First, I need to extract all key clinical data systematically. The core features are: 1) history of mild TBI with persistent headaches despite normal imaging, 2) escalating opioid use beginning with prescribed morphine then transitioning to heroin, 3) physiological dependence evidenced by withdrawal symptoms and failed detox attempts, 4) high-risk behaviors like doctor shopping and intravenous drug use, 5) near-fatal overdose, and 6) functional decline affecting marriage and work.

For diagnostic reasoning, the opioid use disorder appears most prominent given the clear pattern of escalating use, loss of control, continued use despite harm, and physiological dependence. The chronic headache pain needs separate coding since it's both a consequence of TBI and a factor in the substance use. The TBI itself isn't a psychiatric diagnosis but contributes to the clinical picture.

The differential should prioritize conditions directly supported by the vignette. Other substance disorders or psychiatric conditions aren't indicated since the patient's distress appears centered on pain and opioid use without described mood or anxiety symptoms. The treatment request for buprenorphine/naloxone strongly confirms the opioid use disorder diagnosis.

The response format requires precise DSM-5-TR diagnoses with ICD-10 codes. I'll list opioid use disorder as primary given its severity and life-threatening consequences, followed by chronic pain related to the TBI as it's clinically significant and separate from the substance use disorder.
